{{Year nav topic5|1573|music}}
== Events == * Approximate formation date of the [[Florentine Camerata]], at the salon of Count Giovanni de' Bardi (earliest record is January 14, 1573). *[[Manuel Rodrigues Coelho]] becomes organist of [[Badajoz Cathedral]].
== Publications ==
* [[Cipriano de Rore]], ''Sacrae cantiones'' (pub. by [[Pierre Phalèse]])
== Births ==
*[[January 31]] **[[Ambrosius Metzger]], German composer and [[Meistersinger]] **[[Giulio Cesare Monteverdi]] (baptized), Italian composer, younger brother of [[Claudio Monteverdi]] *[[February 22]] – [[Gemignano Capilupi]], Italian composer *[[July 19]] (baptized) – [[Inigo Jones]], English stage designer and architect (died 1652) *''date unknown'' **[[Francesco Colombini]], Italian composer and organist **[[Benedikt Faber]], German composer **[[Juan de Palomares]], Spanish composer and guitarist **[[Alessandro Striggio (ii)|Alessandro Striggio]] the younger, Italian composer *''probable'' – [[Géry de Ghersem]], Flemish composer and singer (died 1630) ** [[Cesarina Ricci de Tingoli]], Italian composer.
== Deaths == *[[March 15]] (or earlier) – [[Christopher Tye]], English composer (born c1505) *[[November 17]] – [[Joannes Pionnier]], French composer *[[December 7]] – John Thorne, English composer and poet *[[December 27]]–[[December 31]] – [[Firmin Lebel]], French chorus director and composer *''date unknown'' **[[Johannes Claux]], Flemish composer **[[Melchior Kreisstein]], German music printer **[[Gislain Manilius]], Flemish music printer **[[Pierre Phalèse the Elder]], Flemish music publisher *''probable'' – [[Alfonso dalla Viola]], Italian composer and instrumentalist
[[Category:1573|Music]] [[Category:16th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

{{Year nav topic5|1671|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1671'''.
==Events== *February – [[Nell Gwyn]] retires from the stage and moves into a brick [[townhouse]] at [[79 Pall Mall]], London.<ref>{{cite book|editor=Sheppard, F. H. W.|chapter=No. 79 Pall Mall: Nell Gwynne's house|series=Survey of London vol. 29-30|title=St James Westminster, Pt 1|pages=377–378|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.asp?compid=40600|year=1960|accessdate=2013-07-12}}</ref> *[[November 9]] – The [[Duke's Company]] open their new venue, the [[Dorset Garden Theatre]]. *[[Antoinette du Ligier de la Garde Deshoulières]] is awarded the first prize given for poetry by the [[Académie française]].<ref>{{cite book|last=France|first=Peter|title=The New Oxford Companion to Literature in French|page=234|location=New York|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1995|isbn=0-19-866125-8}}</ref> *Publication of ''Philosophus Autodidactus'', the first [[Latin]] translation of [[Ibn Tufail]]'s 12th century tale ''[[Hayy ibn Yaqdhan]]'', prepared by [[Edward Pococke]] before 1660.
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Edward Bagshaw (theologian)|Edward Bagshaw]] (attributed) – ''The Life and Death of Mr [[Vavasor Powell]]'' *[[Edward Burrough]] (posthumously): ''The Memorable Works of a Son of Thunder and Consolation: Namely, that True Prophet, and Faithful Servant of God, and Sufferer for the Testimony of Jesus, Edward Burroughs...'' *[[Johann Ferdinand Hertodt]] – ''Crocologia'' *[[John Josselyn]] – ''New England's Rarities, discovered in Birds, Beasts, Fishes, Serpents, and Plants of that Country'' (London) *[[Gottfried Leibniz]] – ''Hypothesis Physica Nova (`New Physical Hypothesis')'' *[[Arnoldus Montanus]] – ''De nieuwe en Onbekende Weereld of Beschryving van America (The Unknown New World or Description of the Continent America)'' *[[Isaac Newton]] – ''[[Method of Fluxions]]'' *[[Jane Sharp]] – ''The Midwives Book: or the Whole Art of Midwifry Discovered'' *[[Marie-Catherine de Villedieu]] – ''Les Amours des Grands Hommes''
===Children=== *[[James Janeway]] – ''A Token for Children'' (two parts)
===Drama=== *[[Aphra Behn]] – ''The Amorous Prince'' (adapted from [[Robert Davenport (dramatist)|Robert Davenport]]'s ''The City Nightcap'') *[[Pierre Corneille]] – ''Tite et Bérénice'' *[[John Crowne]] – ''Juliana, or the Princess of Poland'' *[[John Dryden]] – ''The Assignation, or Love in a Nunnery'' *[[Edward Howard (playwright)|Edward Howard]] – ''The Six Days' Adventure, or the New Utopia'' *[[Elizabeth Polwheele]] – ''The Frolicks'' *[[Edward Ravenscroft]] – ''Mamamouchi'' *[[Elkanah Settle]] – ''Cambyses'' *[[George Villiers, 2nd Duke of Buckingham]] & others – ''[[The Rehearsal (play)|The Rehearsal]]'' *[[William Wycherley]] – ''Love in a Wood'' *[[Pedro Calderon de la Barca]] – ''El santo rey don Fernando''
===Poetry=== *[[John Milton]] – ''[[Samson Agonistes]]''
==Births== *[[April 6]] – [[Jean-Baptiste Rousseau]], French dramatist and poet (died [[1741 in literature|1741]]) *[[June 11]] – [[Colley Cibber]], English playwright and [[Poet Laureate of the United Kingdom|Poet Laureate]] (died [[1757 in literature|1757]]) *[[September 7]] – [[Antoine Danchet]], French dramatist and poet (died [[1748 in literature|1748]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Gustaf Adlerfelt]], Swedish historian (died [[1709 in literature|1709]]) *''Unknown date, possibly 1672'' – [[Sarah Dixon]], English poet (died [[1765 in literature|1765]])
==Deaths== *[[January 1]] – [[Hardouin de Péréfixe de Beaumont]], French historian and cleric (born [[1606 in literature|1606]]) *[[January 22]] – [[Odorico Raynaldi]], Italian historian (born [[1595 in literature|1595]]) *[[February 22]] – [[Adam Olearius]], German librarian and scholar (born [[1603 in literature|1603]]) *[[July 14]] – [[Méric Casaubon]], Swiss-born English classicist (born [[1599 in literature|1599]]) *[[September 28]] – [[Jean de Montigny]], French philosopher and poet (born [[1636 in literature|1636]]) *[[December 28]] – [[Johann Friedrich Gronovius]], German classicist (born [[1611 in literature|1611]])

[[Image:Aghadoe cathedral April 2010.JPG|thumb|300px|Remains of Aghadoe Cathedral]] '''Aghadoe Cathedral''' was a church that may have been the seat of a bishop at [[Aghadoe]], [[Ireland]] (later joined with the [[Bishop of Ardfert and Aghadoe|Bishopric of Ardfert]]). The now ruined [[cathedral]] overlooks the [[Lakes of Killarney]] from [[Aghadoe]], a few miles from [[Killarney]]. Aghadoe may have been the site of a church as early as the seventh century, but extant remains are of a stone structure built in the eleventh and twelfth centuries.
==History== Aghadoe, ([[Irish language|Irish]]: ''Achadh Deo'' "place with two yews"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.all-ireland.com/attractions/munster/kerry/aghadoe.htm |accessdate=June 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |title=All Ireland Travel |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707112521/http://www.all-ireland.com/attractions/munster/kerry/aghadoe.htm |archivedate=July 7, 2011 }}</ref>) may have begun as a pagan religious site.<ref>Long, Tom. "Tracing Our Faith." ''Fossa & Aghadoe: Our Heritage and History''. ed. Jim Larner. Fossa Historical Society. 2007. {{ISBN|978-0-9557739-0-7}}. p 1.</ref> The site has also been associated with the fifth century missionary [[St. Abban]], but seventh century [[ogham]] stones mark the first clear evidence of Aghadoe being used as an important site.<ref name="Long1">Long, 1.</ref> According to legend, [[St. Finian Lobhar|St. Finian]] founded a monastery at Aghadoe in the sixth or seventh century. The first written record of a monastery dates from 939 AD in the [[Annals of Innisfallen]] where the Aghadoe monastery is referred to as the "Old Abbey."<ref name="Long1"/> The monastery at Aghadoe had a close relationship with the one on nearby [[Innisfallen Island]]. [[Maelsuthain O'Carroll]], one of Innisfallen's greatest scholars, was buried at Aghadoe after his death in 1010 AD, and a legend suggests that the two monasteries were connected by a causeway across [[Loch Lein]].<ref name="Long1"/> In 1027 the Annals make the first reference to a stone building on the site, noting the construction of Damh Liag Maenig (Maenach’s house of stone). Construction on the [[Irish round tower|round tower]] began the same year.<ref name="Long1"/> Aghadoe witnessed the turbulence of the times. In 1061, an O'Cathail, the heir to the local dynasty of [[Eóganacht Locha Léin]], was taken from the church and murdered.<ref name="Long2">Long, 2.</ref>
In the middle of the twelfth century Amhlaoibh Mór Ó Donoghue, the leader of the Ó Donoghue—the new rulers of Eóganacht Locha Léin, had a new church building, later called the "Great Church," constructed in the [[romanesque architecture|Romanesque style]] and dedicated to the [[Holy Trinity]]. The new structure, completed in 1158, incorporated part of the old stone building in its northwest section and makes up the western section of the extant remains.<ref name="Long2"/> When Amhlaoibh Mór Ó Donoghue was killed, his body was carried to Aghadoe and interred in the church.<ref name="Long3">Long, 3.</ref> The final addition to the church was constructed in the twelfth century. The addition served as a [[chancel]] or [[choir]], and was later separated from the rest of the church by a wall.<ref name="Long3"/>
After being incorporated into the Bishopric of Ardfert, Aghadoe operated as a parish church under an [[archdeacon]]. The church is mentioned in a 1615 report, but it is excluded from a list of abbeys in the report suggesting it had become only an archdeaconry. The town of Aghadoe was sacked in the 1650s by [[Oliver Cromwell|Cromwell's]] forces. By 1740, Aghadoe is no longer listed as an active parish and seems to have ceased functioning.<ref>Long, 4.</ref>
==Artifacts== Two [[Ogham|ogham stones]] have been found at Aghadoe. One is currently cemented in the south wall of the chancel and bears an inscription transcribed as "BRRUANANN" The inscription may have actually been intended as "BRREANANN," a possible reference to [[St. Brendan]].<ref name="Long6">Long, 6.</ref> A second ogham stone has since gone missing, but its inscription was transcribed as "GGVVSS MN."<ref name="Long6"/> The presence of these ogham stones suggests the site's importance dates back to the mid-seventh century.<ref name="Long6"/> Another early Christian artifact, a [[bullaun]], can be found outside of church by the northwest corner of the nave.<ref>"The Cathedrals of the [[Church of Ireland]]" [[John Godfrey FitzMaurice Day|Day, J.G.F./]] [[Henry Edmund Patton|Patton, H.E.]] p159: [[London]], [[SPCK|S.P.C.K.]], [[1932]]</ref> The bullaun may have been originally been used as a [[quern-stone]], but it was later used as a holy water receptacle and rainwater collected in the hollow of the stone had healing properties according to lore.<ref>Long, 7.</ref>
[[File:Aghadoe Cathedral western doorway romanesque April 2010.jpg|thumb|Western dooryway of the cathedral with Romanesque carvings]] The "Aghadoe Crosier" from Aghadoe was made of walrus ivory and carved in the [[Urnes style]] of the Vikings. The carvings are similar to those on the [[jambs]] of Romanesque doorway to the cathedral.<ref>{{cite book | last = Sawyer | first = Peter | title = The Age of the Vikings and before / Peter Sawyer | publisher = Oxford : Oxford University Press | location = Oxford | year = 2001 | isbn = 978-0-19-285434-6 }} p. 108.</ref> Another crosier, possibly associated with Aghadoe,<!-- Source refers to it as the "Aghadoe Crozier," but its clearly different from the current one. Probably what is now known as the Innisfallen Crozier. --> was found in the lakes in 1867 by a fisherman who thought it was a salmon.<ref>{{cite journal |last=O'Donoghue |first=Denis |title=The Aghadoe Crozier |journal=Journal of the Cork Historical and Archæological Society |publisher=Cork Historical and Archæological Society |volume=5 Second series |year=1899 |location=Cork, Ireland |pages=235–243 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wg97AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA235&lpg=PA235&dq=aghadoe+crozier&source=bl&ots=rqEeKx_kBg&sig=u6Z5VxIAlThxo2DaJyPoDxwkaf0&hl=en&ei=cxxVTJWVHYL68Aa-vYD_BA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=aghadoe%20crozier&f=false }}</ref>
According to the ''Annals of Innisfallen'', Aghadoe Cathedral's [[high cross]] toppled in a strong wind in 1282.<ref>{{cite book | last = Sheehan | first = John | title = Early Medieval Munster | publisher = Cork University Press | location = Cork | year = 1998 | isbn = 978-1-85918-107-2 }} p. 145</ref>
[[File:Sculpture carving fragment aghadoe.jpg|thumb|Seventeenth century carving of the crucifixion]] A carved stone fragment found on the site is thought to date from the seventeenth century. It depicts the crucifixion with a female figure passing a chalice to Christ on the cross. The stone suggests Aghadoe was still used as a religious site during the seventeenth century.<ref>Long, 6-7.</ref>
<gallery> File:Aghadoe cathedral from west 1892.png|1892 sketch of Aghadoe Cathedral File:Aghadoe cathedral west doorway detail 1892.png|Detail of the doorway File:Aghadoe cathedral round tower 1892.png|1892 sketch of the remains of the round tower </gallery>
